verses.text: After these acts of faithfulness, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, came and invaded Judah, and encamped against the fortified cities, intending to conquer them for himself.
verses.comment: The invasion occurs after Hezekiah's faithfulness, demonstrating that obedience to God does not exempt believers from trials.

verses.text: When Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib had come and intended to fight against Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s recognition of the threat prompts the narrative towards his preparations and trust in God.

verses.text: he consulted with his officials and his warriors about stopping the waters of the springs that were outside the city, and they helped him.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s wisdom and collaboration with his leaders shows faithful stewardship, balancing prayer with prudent action.

verses.text: A great many people gathered, and they stopped all the springs and the stream that flowed through the land, saying, 'Why should the kings of Assyria come and find much water?'
verses.comment: Denying the attackers access to water was a practical defensive measure; see also Isaiah’s account of these preparations.

verses.text: He took courage, rebuilt all the broken wall sections, raised towers on it, and built another wall outside. He strengthened the Millo in the city of David, and made weapons and shields in abundance.
verses.comment: Rebuilding broken defenses illustrates the theme that divine promises do not negate the believer’s responsibility to act.

verses.text: He set commanders of war over the people, gathered them to him in the open square at the city gate, and encouraged them with these words:
verses.comment: Hezekiah emerges here as both a spiritual and civic leader, providing encouragement modeled after Israel’s past leaders.

verses.text: 'Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or dismayed because of the king of Assyria and all the multitude with him, for there are more with us than with him.'
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s words echo the encouragement God gave Joshua and Elijah, pointing to the invisible reality of God’s aid.

verses.text: 'With him is only the arm of flesh, but with us is the LORD our God to help us and to fight our battles.' And the people were encouraged by the words of Hezekiah king of Judah.
verses.comment: Trusting in God’s power above human strength is a consistent biblical theme, related to spiritual battle and faith.

verses.text: After this, Sennacherib king of Assyria, who was besieging Lachish with all his forces, sent his servants to Jerusalem, to Hezekiah king of Judah and to all the people of Judah who were in Jerusalem, saying:
verses.comment: Sennacherib’s psychological warfare includes a direct message to all Jerusalem, involving the whole community of believers.

verses.text: 'Thus says Sennacherib king of Assyria: “On what do you rest this confidence of yours while you remain under siege in Jerusalem?'
verses.comment: The enemy seeks to undermine faith by questioning where the people’s confidence truly rests—paralleling the serpent’s doubts in Genesis 3.

verses.text: 'Is not Hezekiah misleading you, to give you over to die by famine and thirst, when he tells you, ‘The LORD our God will deliver us from the hand of the king of Assyria’?'
verses.comment: A direct assault is made against the people’s trust in their spiritual leader and in God’s promises.

verses.text: 'Has not this same Hezekiah removed his high places and his altars, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, “You shall worship before one altar, and on it you shall burn incense”?'
verses.comment: Sennacherib misunderstands true worship, seeing Hezekiah’s removal of foreign altars as a weakening of religious power, missing the scriptural mandate for unified worship at one altar (Deut. 12:5-14).

verses.text: 'Do you not know what I and my fathers have done to all the peoples of other lands? Were the gods of the nations of those lands able to deliver their lands out of my hand?'
verses.comment: Here the Assyrian king arrogantly equates the God of Israel with pagan idols, anticipating the New Testament’s contrast between the one true God and false gods (see 1 Cor. 8:4-6).

verses.text: 'Who among all the gods of those nations that my fathers utterly destroyed was able to deliver his people from my hand, that your God should be able to deliver you from my hand?'
verses.comment: The king’s challenge highlights the uniqueness of Israel’s faith, prefiguring the ultimate defense of God’s people through divine intervention.

verses.text: 'Now therefore, do not let Hezekiah deceive you or mislead you in this way, and do not believe him; for no god of any nation or kingdom has been able to deliver his people from my hand or from the hand of my fathers. How much less will your God deliver you from my hand!'
verses.comment: This verse shows a repeated motif—doubt sown about God’s power—contrasted by later miraculous deliverance, pointing toward New Testament lessons about persevering in faith.

verses.text: And his servants said still more against the LORD God and against his servant Hezekiah.
verses.comment: Attacks against God’s anointed often accompany attacks on faith itself, a foreshadow of future opposition to Christ’s appointed leaders.

verses.text: He also wrote letters to cast contempt on the LORD, the God of Israel, and to speak against Him, saying, 'As the gods of the nations of the lands have not delivered their people from my hand, so the God of Hezekiah will not deliver His people from my hand.'
verses.comment: Written blasphemy sets the stage for public vindication of God’s name, much as in the confrontations between Elijah and the prophets of Baal (1 Kings 18).

verses.text: They called out loudly in the language of Judah to the people of Jerusalem who were on the wall, to frighten and terrify them, in order to capture the city.
verses.comment: Using the people’s own language was a tactic to sow fear, showing the enemy’s cunning. Christ’s faithfulness later conquers such fear (see John 16:33).

verses.text: They spoke of the God of Jerusalem as though He were like the gods of the peoples of the earth, works of men’s hands.
verses.comment: The Assyrian envoys, misunderstanding Israel’s faith, equated Yahweh with powerless idols made by humans, displaying both cultural ignorance and arrogance; this sets the stage for God’s unique intervention, as seen in Exodus 15:11 and Psalm 115:3-8, which contrast the living God with man-made gods.

verses.text: Then King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz prayed about this and cried to heaven.
verses.comment: Here is a model of united intercessory prayer between the king and prophet, symbolizing harmony between spiritual and civil authority in seeking God’s intervention.

verses.text: And the LORD sent an angel, who destroyed every mighty warrior, commander, and officer in the camp of the king of Assyria. So he returned in shame to his own land. When he entered the house of his god, his own sons killed him there with the sword.
verses.comment: God’s deliverance surpasses any natural explanation, reminiscent of angelic interventions throughout biblical history (e.g., Exod. 12:29; Matt. 28:2).

verses.text: So the LORD saved Hezekiah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem from the hand of Sennacherib king of Assyria and from the hand of all others, and guided them on every side.
verses.comment: Deliverance and guidance are paired as twin manifestations of God’s saving grace, foreshadowing the fullness of salvation in Christ.

verses.text: And many brought gifts to the LORD in Jerusalem and presents to Hezekiah king of Judah, so that he was exalted in the sight of all nations from that time onward.
verses.comment: The nations’ homage prefigures messianic prophecies of the nations worshiping God in Jerusalem (Isa. 2:2-3; cf. Matt. 2:11).

verses.text: In those days Hezekiah became mortally ill, and he prayed to the LORD, and He spoke to him and gave him a sign.
verses.comment: God’s granting of a miraculous sign in response to prayer echoes New Testament accounts of Christ’s healing power and affirmation of faith (see John 4:48).

verses.text: But Hezekiah did not repay the favor shown to him, for his heart was proud. Therefore, wrath came upon him and Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The dangers of pride following great blessings are a recurring scriptural lesson, highlighting the importance of humility for all God’s people.

verses.text: But Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart, he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the wrath of the LORD did not come upon them during the days of Hezekiah.
verses.comment: Humility and repentance lead to God’s mercy, a foundational principle throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Hezekiah had very great riches and honor. And he made treasuries for his silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and for all kinds of desirable articles;
verses.comment: Riches are presented as blessings from God when received with gratitude and humility (cf. Prov. 3:9-10).

verses.text: storehouses also for the produce of grain, wine, and oil, and stalls for all kinds of livestock and folds for the flocks.
verses.comment: Prudent stewardship and preparation echo Joseph’s example in Egypt.

verses.text: He built cities for himself and acquired flocks and herds in abundance, for God had given him great possessions.
verses.comment: Material prosperity is attributed to the Lord’s provision, not merely human effort.

verses.text: This same Hezekiah stopped the upper outlet of the waters of Gihon, and directed them straight down to the west side of the city of David. Hezekiah prospered in all his works.
verses.comment: Engineering feats such as the Siloam tunnel are seen as God-blessed achievements for the good of God’s people.

verses.text: But when ambassadors came from Babylon to inquire about the sign that had happened in the land, God left Hezekiah to test him, that He might know all that was in his heart.
verses.comment: God testing the hearts of leaders is a recurring motif, and can be seen as a spiritual examination relevant to all believers.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and his good deeds, are written in the vision of Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, and in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.comment: Chronicles reference a broader canonical tradition, affirming the importance of sacred history and its preservation by inspired writers.

verses.text: So Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and they buried him on the ascent to the tombs of the sons of David; and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem honored him at his death. And Manasseh his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s honored burial recalls the tradition of veneration for righteous ancestors, a practice fulfilled in the ultimate honor given to the saints in Christ.
